Stabenow: What happens when farmers and ranchers have fewer options? What are the immediate effects? And what are the unintended consequences? Those are the questions I hope we can begin to answer today.

Stabenow: With fewer companies ‚Äì and more foreign-owned companies ‚Äìcontrolling more of the marketplace, there is a widening gap between those giant players and the small- and medium-sized processors that many local farmers and ranchers count on.
Stabenow: USDA‚Äôs Packers and Stockyards Division data show that four companies account for 85% of fed cattle slaughter.

Stabenow: The pandemic made clear how important the food resiliency conversation is. Early last year, shifts in demand forced producers to plow under crops and dump milk. At the same time, consumers panicked at empty store shelves, and food banks faced lines of waiting cars.

Stabenow: USDA has announced a new grant program to help small processors upgrade their plants to meet Federal inspection standards. That will help smaller processors boost their capacity and meet increased demand while providing more opportunities for small livestock producers.

Stabenow: Many of us have heard from producers concerned with a lack of transparency and competition. These farmers and ranchers also raise concerns with concentration in the packing industry, potential market manipulation, lack of access to small- and mid-size plants.

As I entered public life, what impressed me most about John was his obvious belief that country and character count above all else. He was a Republican and I am a Democrat‚Äîbut that never mattered. He never hesitated to prioritize his country over the orthodoxy of the day.

Long before I knew John Warner the patriotic public servant, I was honored to consider John a friend. It was only upon coming to the Senate‚Äîfour years after he retired‚Äîthat I came to fully understand the mark he left on the Senate, his beloved Commonwealth, and his country.
